talk.start.para: —The Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: and (2) Two personal staff employed at the adviser level have job descriptions involving media and communications. The salary rates for the above-mentioned roles are available in the Commonwealth Members of Parliament Staff Collective Agreement 2006-2009 available on the Parliament of Australia intranet site.

For the number of staff in the Department with the roles of media relations, media advice, public relations, public affairs, communications and communications strategy, please refer to Parliamentary Question on Notice – Senate 024. Their salary rates are provided in the FaHCSIA Collective Agreement 2009-11, available on www.fahcsia.gov.au.

The rate of employer contribution to superannuation will vary according to the governing rules of the CSS, PSS or PSSap superannuation schemes, or as determined by the employing organisation in relation to private superannuation funds (subject to minimum obligations as legislated). The employer superannuation contributions may range from nine per cent to 33.8 per cent of salary, depending on scheme membership.

The aggregate travel costs during the 2008 calendar year to 24 November 2008 for relevant staff in Minister Macklin’s Office was $49,548.12. (Travel costs have been provided by the Department of Finance and Deregulation and are up to and including 24 November 2008. No Costs are included for any travel after 24 November 2008.).
The aggregate travel costs during the 2008 calendar year to 24 November 2008 for relevant staff in the department was $84,808.06.
The aggregate mobile phone costs during the 2008 calendar year to 24 November 2008 for relevant staff in Minister Macklin’s Office was $6,064.35.
I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources to collect and assemble the highly detailed information sought in part b of the honourable Senator’s question..

There are many informal and semi-formal departmental activities that could fall under the rubric of committee work. Tabulating this level of activity would be excessively onerous. Therefore, the information provided below focuses on publicly announced committees initiated by the Department or by one of the portfolio Ministers. Work for Cabinet committees, inter‑departmental committees, Council of Australian Governments (COAG) Working Groups and internal committees are explicitly excluded.

Reviews currently being undertaken in the portfolio/agency or affecting the portfolio/agency are as previously indicated in Question on Notice 31 to Senator Bernardi (2008 Supplementary Estimates, October 2008). Further information was subsequently provided by way of Question on Notice 55 to Senator Humphries (2009 Additional Estimates, February 2009), which mentioned that:
The Pension Review, which forms part of the broader Inquiry into Australia’s Future Tax System, was completed on 28 February 2009;
the National Council to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children review was concluded on 19 March 2009;

a Productivity Commission’s review of the contribution of the not-for-profit sector to Australian society, which was announced by the Government on 17 March 2009 is anticipated to conclude at the end of December 2009;
a Print Disability Program (PDP) review is due to report at the end of October 2009;
a National Disability Advocacy Program (NDAP) review has been finalised and the report is being considered by the Department; and
a post-implementation review of the National Rental Affordability Scheme is due to report at the end of October 2009.

Adopting the same definitional scope to the previous question, and supplementing the previous answer to this question in October 2008 [Supplementary Estimates Question 31], the “in progress” and “incomplete” reviews, inquiries and committees announced between 1 December 2007 and 24 November 2008 (and associated reporting dates) are:

entry.para: National Council to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children

item.para: The staffing numbers allocated to these reviews vary over time. I am not prepared to commit the level of departmental resources required to answer these parts of the Honourable Senator’s questions.
The external consultants and their costs are detailed in the Department’s 2007-08 and 2008‑09 Annual Reports.

I am not prepared to commit the level of Departmental resources required to answer the honourable Senator’s question concerning the total cost of each departmental review, inquiry and committee, including staff wages, consultancy costs, travel and any other associated expenditure for the 2008 calendar year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy, upon notice, on 17 September 2009:

item.para: What is the estimated monthly cost for household access to broadband under the new NBN?

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: How much of the rollout cost is being paid for by: (i) the Federal Government, and, (ii) the Tasmanian Government; and (b) for each, what is its proportion and cost to date?

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: What has been the total cost of the rollout to date; (b) what is the projected total cost of the rollout; and (c) can a breakdown be provided of these costs, specifically, the legal costs associated with the NBN in Tasmania?

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: What has been the standard cost to date spent on consultancies associated with the NBN in Tasmania; and (b) can be a breakdown of the cost of each consultancy be provided?

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: What parts of Tasmania will have access to the NBN; (b) what is the estimated time frame for these areas to receive access; and (c) which areas will not have access?
Of the $43 billion cost of the national rollout, how much has been allocated for the rollout in Tasmania?
Was a feasibility study conducted on the merits of the NBN in Tasmania; if so can a copy be provided?
Is there a report on the status of the NBN rollout in Tasmania; if so can a copy be provided?
Have any studies been conducted on the uptake of the NBN in Tasmania; if so: (a) what were the results of these studies; and (b) can a copy of each study be provided?
Has the Tasmanian Government provided a submission/ report to the Federal Government in relation to the NBN in Tasmania; if so, can a copy of each study be provided?

Were any other stakeholders invited to make a submission/ report to the Federal Government regarding the NBN in Tasmania; if so (a) who was invited; and (b) can copies of these submissions/ reports be provided?
How can the Federal Government guarantee both commercial viability and affordable prices in Tasmania?
(a) What assets does the Tasmania NBN own; (b) how many employees does it employ; and (c) how many consultants has it contracted?

talker.name: Conroy, Sen Stephen
talker.role: Minister for Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy
talker.name: Senator Conroy

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honorable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: The costs for household access will be determined by wholesale costs set by NBN Tasmania and retail service providers that use the NBN in order to supply broadband services. NBN Tasmania Limited is currently in negotiations with retail service providers on product and service arrangements. Ultimately retail service providers will set retail prices in a competitive market.

The costs of the rollout will be met by NBN Tasmania Limited. NBN Tasmania Limited is a subsidiary of NBN Co and has been established to build and operate the NBN in Tasmania. It will receive equity contributions from the Australian Government through NBN Co and negotiations for the vending in of assets held by the State of Tasmania and Aurora Energy are continuing. A $100 million equity injection towards the cost of the rollout of the Stages 1, 2 and 3 was announced on 1 March 2010.

Construction costs incurred by NBN Tasmania Limited under the stage one rollout agreement to 31 December 2009 are approximately $3.707 million. Final costs for the first stage in Tasmania will be determined once the competitive tender processes conducted by Aurora Energy and NBN Tasmania Limited are completed. Legal costs associated with the NBN in Tasmania will also not be known until the tender processes are complete. However to 31 December 2009, the Department has incurred approximately $510,962 in legal costs and $21,129 for the Australian Government Solicitor for advice associated with the negotiations with the Tasmanian Government and Aurora Energy and the establishment of NBN Tasmania Limited.

The Department of Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy has incurred the following costs to 31 December 2009 to establish NBN Tasmania Limited and conduct negotiations with the Tasmanian Government and Aurora Energy: approximately $266,554 on commercial consultants, KPMG; approximately $277,623 on technical consultants, Consultel IT&T: and approximately $510,962 on legal consultants, Minter Ellison.

200,000 Tasmanian premises will be connected by fibre optic cable and the remaining premises will be connected via wireless and satellite technologies. The NBN will be rolled out in Tasmania over the next five years.

NBN Tasmania and Aurora Energy are currently conducting tender processes for services and resources to supply the rollout. In order to achieve the best value for taxpayers’ money it is not appropriate to release the funding allocation for the Tasmania rollout.

The Government entered into negotiations with the Tasmanian Government based on the advice of the Panel of Experts, which was engaged to advise the Government on the previous Request for Proposals process.

The first stage rollout in Tasmania has commenced. The communities of Smithton, Scottsdale and Midway Point will be the first to receive optical fibre broadband connections. Corning Cable Systems is the successful tenderer to supply fibre optic cable -- backhaul and FTTP -- for stage one. John Holland is the successful tenderer to construct the backhaul and FTTP, and BSA the successful tenderer to install the cable drops. The backhaul links to Midway Point and Smithton are now completed and work continues on the backhaul to Scottsdale. Construction work will be underway in the three stage 1 communities in March 2010. The first three retail service providers (Primus, iiNet and Internode) who will provide services over the NBN were announced on 13 March 2010.
NBN Tasmania Limited has not conducted a take-up study.

In 2008 the Tasmanian Government submitted a commercial-in-confidence proposal to the Government as part of the National Broadband Network Request for Proposals (RFP) process. The Tasmanian Government proposal is covered by confidentiality provisions under the RFP and will not be released.
No.

The Government recognises that affordability is an important factor that will drive take-up of services on the NBN, and in turn viability. As a wholesale-only network, the NBN will deliver genuine competition, choice and affordable services supporting the future needs of Australia. Pricing on the NBN will need to have careful regard to existing price points in the market. As in today’s market, there will be a range of plans and price points to meet the needs of home and business customers.

NBN Tasmania Limited has been established to build and operate the NBN in Tasmania. As the network assets are progressively built, commissioned, tested and accepted the ownership of those assets transfers to NBN Tasmania. NBN Tasmania currently has a General Manager, an Executive Director and five non-executive directors with several specialists seconded from NBN Co to lead the program management, commercial, industry engagement and operations activities. In addition there is a core team of up to 20 people in Aurora (as agent for NBN Tasmania) performing the network design and managing the supply and construction activities of sub-contractors. Professional services are provided by Minter Ellison as interim Company Secretary.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 December 2009:

quote.para: Why are the managing directors and boards of directors of Burmese regime’s largest earning company, the military‑owned Myanmar Oil and Gas Enterprise, not on the Australian financial sanctions list, while managing directors and boards of directors of other military‑owned enterprises, such as Bandoola Transportation Co., Myawaddy Trading Co., Myanmar Brewery Ltd, Union of Myanmar Economic Holdings Ltd, Myanmar Land and Development and Hsinmin Cement Plant Construction Project are.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator Faulkner

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: Mr Smith indicated in his Ministerial Statement of 8 February 2010 that the Burma sanctions list announced in October 2008 will remain in operation for the present.

Consistent with past practice, any update to the sanctions list will take into account personnel movements in the regime and further information about members of the State Peace and Development Council, ministers, senior military officers, prominent business associates of the regime, and immediate family members of these individuals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 8 February 2010:

item.para: On how many occasions has the current and/or former Minister and associated parliamentary secretaries in the current parliament, and any departmental officials: (a) met directly with representatives of Hawker Britton; and/or (b) attended meetings that were also attended by representatives of Hawker Britton.
For each abovementioned meeting: (a) what was the date; (b) what was the topic of discussion; and (c) which Hawker Britton representatives were present.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator Faulkner

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade have provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: Responding to this question would require departmental officials to review calendar and diary entries since December 2007 for meetings that may have involved or been attended by Hawker Britton. This would require the manual examination of a large number of diary and meeting records, which is an unreasonable diversion of government resources.

Conducting the same searches across the diary records of current ministers and parliamentary secretaries in this portfolio would be an unreasonable diversion of resources for similar reasons. The records of former parliamentary secretaries are considered personal information in many circumstances and no access to those records will be sought.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Environment Protection, Heritage and the Arts, upon notice, on 8 February 2010:

item.para: On how many occasions has the current and/or former Minister and associated parliamentary secretaries in the current parliament, and any departmental officials: (a) met directly with representatives of Hawker Britton; and/or (b) attended meetings that were also attended by representatives of Hawker Britton.
For each abovementioned meeting: (a) what was the date; (b) what was the topic of discussion; and (c) which Hawker Britton representatives were present.

talker.name: Wong, Sen Penny
talker.role: Minister for Climate Change, Energy Efficiency and Water
talker.name: Senator Wong

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Environment Protection, Heritage and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: Responding to this question would require Departmental officials to review calendar and diary entries since December 2007 for meetings that may have involved or been attended by Hawker Britton. This would require the manual examination of a large number of diary and meeting records, which is an unreasonable diversion of government resources.

Conducting the same searches across the diary records of current ministers and parliamentary secretaries in this portfolio would be an unreasonable diversion of resources for similar reasons. The records of former ministers and parliamentary secretaries are considered personal information in many circumstances and no access to those records will be sought.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator Faulkner

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Attached are the grant applications and expenditure reports under the Australian Political Parties for democracy Program for 2006-07:
Attachment A1* – Australian Labour Party grant application 2006-07
Attachment A2* – Liberal Party of Australia grant application 2006-07
Attachment A3* – Australian Labour Party expenditure report 2006-07
Attachment A4* – Liberal Party of Australia expenditure report 2006-07

item.label: (b)
item.para: Attached are the grant applications and expenditure reports under the Australian Political Parties for democracy Program for 2007-08:
Attachment B1* – Australian Labour Party grant application 2007-08
Attachment B2* – Liberal Party of Australia grant application 2007-08

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 February 2010:

quote.para: With reference to the public revelations that an MI5 [United Kingdom Security Service] officer travelled to Pakistan to help interrogate British terror suspect Mr Binyam Mohamed, despite previous MI5 assurances to parliament of no such involvement in Mr Mohamed’s ill treatment, can the Government confirm that no:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Australian officers were involved in, or present at, any interrogation process in Pakistan or Egypt, including that of Mr Mamdouh Habib; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: government agent or instrumentality, now or in the past, has been involved in, or present at, such procedures with anyone.

talker.name: Wong, Sen Penny
talker.role: Minister for Climate Change, Energy Efficiency and Water
talker.name: Senator Wong

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Government confirms that officers from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) were granted access to visit Mr Habib in Pakistan on 24, 26 and 29 October 2001 for the purpose of conducting an interview with Mr Habib. The Australian Federal Police was present at interviews on 26 and 29 October 2001 to identify any law enforcement interests.
The Government confirms that no Australian officers had any dealings with Mr Habib in Egypt. The Government of Egypt, however, has never officially confirmed that it held Mr Habib in its custody.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Australians detained overseas are from time to time interviewed by Australian intelligence and law enforcement officials. The Australian Government has a longstanding practice of not commenting publicly on the details of intelligence matters.

talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator Faulkner

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade have provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

subdebateinfo.title: Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government: Staffing

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, upon notice, on 25 February 2010:

quote.para: With reference to the department and all agencies in the Minister’s portfolio, how many redundancies were there for each of the following financial years: (a) 2007-08; (b) 2008-09; and (c) 2009-10 to date.

talker.name: Conroy, Sen Stephen
talker.role: Minister for Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy
talker.name: Senator Conroy

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (c)
item.para: 5 to 28 February 2010

subdebateinfo.title: Strategic Indigenous Housing and Infrastructure Program

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 9 March 2010:

quote.para: With reference to the houses on Groote Eylandt renovated through the Strategic Indigenous Housing and Infrastructure Program:

item.para: Was a schedule of required work prepared for each house to be renovated; if so, were these schedules provided to the building contractors.
Can a copy be provided of all schedules of work for each renovated house.
Was all work listed on the assessed schedule completed for each house; if not, who was responsible for determining what work: (a) would be completed; and (b) would be left undone.
Who was responsible on behalf of the Commonwealth for: (a) inspection and acceptance of the completed works; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: approval of payment to the Alliance partners.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: How many houses have been renovated;

item.label: (b)
item.para: what is the total amount paid to the Alliance partners for these renovations; and (c) what was the cost per individual house.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Citizenship
talker.name: Senator Chris Evans

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: The Alliance Partner is responsible for the development of a scope of works that includes a detailed breakdown of the various components of work to be undertaken. The relevant sections of the detailed breakdown form the basis of contractual arrangements with building contractors engaged by the Alliance Partners.
Current schedules are detailed and contain commercial in confidence information including the schedule of rates and therefore cannot be made available.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: and (b) A condition assessment report carried out on each house by the Department of Local Government Housing and Regional Services (DLGHRS) Asset Management Officer (AMO) immediately prior to SIHIP works commencing. The Alliance Partner works with the AMO as the assessment is carried out. This assessment informs the Alliance Partner of a scope of works which is aligned to the SIHIP refurbishment priorities. The AMO and Alliance Partner agree on the scope works to be done within the $75,000 average per house. This process was introduced in January 2010.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Northern Territory Government has responsibility for inspection and acceptance of completed works. DLGHRS AMOs inspect houses on completion to confirm that all that should have been done on the house has been completed and certify that refurbishment houses meet appropriate standards.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Payment is not made house by house. The Northern Territory Government has an Alliance Partnership Agreement with each Alliance Partner that sets out the contractual arrangements and determines how payments are made.

item.label: (a)
item.para: As at 27 April 2010 31 refurbishments were completed on Groote Eylandt with 8 underway.

item.label: (b)
item.para: and (c) Payment is not made house by house. It is not possible to disaggregate payments made to the Alliance Partner for individual communities or houses. The Northern Territory Government has a contract and agreed budget with each Alliance Partner for each package against which payments are scrutinised and monitored.

talk.start.para: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 15 March 2010:

item.para: What has been the nature and cost of all road work on Parliament Drive since (and including) when it was made one-way in 2006, and can an itemised list of the works be provided including a cost and rationale for each item.

With reference to current works on the public car park at Parliament House: (a) how many spaces were available for cars, motorcycles and bicycles before work commenced; and (b) how many spaces will there be once work is completed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Roads works around Parliament Drive between 2005 and 2010 cost $2.05 million (administered capital funding) comprising:

entry.para: Conversion to one way road to eliminate conflicts near Senate and House of Representatives slip roads arising from the installation of slip road bollards.
Post-Operative Review and Traffic Management Report (Road Safety Assessment).
Implementing road safety recommendations from the Traffic Management Report and re-surfacing the road.

item.para: Spaces in the public car park at Parliament House:

entry.para: Inside Restricted Area adjacent to Security Point One and the lift
Reduced central area parking after reorganisation on 22 March 2010.

Diagonal parking on the large driveways/roadways on the East and West sides of the car park is expected to provide 100 additional spaces. This will be subject to a traffic management study currently underway. Note: About 50 additional spaces will be available from 22 March 2010, with the remaining 50 spaces available once concrete kerbs are removed by late May 2010.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, on notice, on 26 March 2010:

quote.para: By state and territory, how many additional training places in language, literacy and numeracy have been created for: (a) the 2008-09 financial year; and (b) the period 1 July 2009 to 1 March 2010.

talker.name: Carr, Sen Kim
talker.role: Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research
talker.name: Senator Carr

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education has provide the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: Additional training places in language, literacy and numeracy over the period outlined in the question from Senator Cormann have been funded in the Workplace English Language and Literacy (WELL) Program and the Language, Literacy and Numeracy Program (LLNP).

There were no additional places for WELL in 2008-09. There are 2,253 additional places allocated through WELL for the period 1 July 2009 to 31 March 2010. Table 1 below, provides a breakdown of those additional places by State / Territory.

para.inline: Additional WELL places for 1 July 2009 to 31 March 2010

quote.para: There was an increase of 748 LLNP commencements in 2008-09 compared with the 17,205 commencements in 2007-08. There were 14,105 commencements in the period 1 July 2009 to 31 March 2010
Table 2 provides a state / territory breakdown of commencements for 2008-09 and the Year-To-Date (YTD) figure for 2009-10 (as at 31 March 2010).

para.inline: Table 2: LLNP Training Commencements in 2008-09 and YTD 2009-10

subdebateinfo.title: Employment and Workplace Relations: Program Funding

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, on notice, on 26 March 2010:

quote.para: By state and territory, how many training places have been created under the 2009-10 Budget measure entitled ‘Skills for the Carbon Challenge.’

talker.name: Arbib, Sen Mark
talker.role: Minister for Employment Participation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Government Service Delivery
talker.name: Senator Arbib

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations has provide the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: The Skills for the Carbon Challenge initiative was announced on 23 April 2009, as part of the Commonwealth Government’s response to the 2020 Summit.

This initiative does not directly fund training places. The purpose of the initiative is to build the capacity of the tertiary sector to supply the skills needed for workers and businesses to prosper in a low-carbon economy. To date, this initiative has supported:

item.para: the development of a number of research projects on the supply and demand of skills for sustainability to build an evidence base to inform future policy development, and
the presentation of the inaugural Skills for Sustainability Award to TAFE NSW – Northern Sydney Institute in November 2009.

quote.para: The Green Skills Agreement between the Australian Government and state and territory governments, which was endorsed by COAG in December 2009, will lead to the provision of skills for sustainability by Registered Training Organisations across all states and territories. The Agreement will ensure that 30 000 apprentices in carbon exposed industries will graduate over the next two years with qualifications that include clean and green skills, and that all new apprentices commencing after 1 January 2010 will graduate with a core set of green skills, knowledge and training.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 March 2010:

quote.para: By state and territory, what was the total of funds expended by the Education Investment Fund for the period 24 November 2007 to 1 March 2010?

talker.name: Carr, Sen Kim
talker.role: Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research
talker.name: Senator Carr

quote.para: For the period 24 November 2007 to 1 March 2010, grant payments totalling $913.5 million have been made under the Education Investment Fund. Successful applicants received grant payments as follows: in New South Wales - $298.3 million, in Victoria - $212.6 million, in Queensland - $168.2 million, in South Australia - $46.6 million, in Western Australia - $64.9 million, in Tasmania - $23.0 million, in the Northern Territory - $19.0 million and in the Australian Capital Territory - $72.6 million. In addition, one successful applicant received grant payments totalling $8.3 million for its campuses in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, on notice, on 26 March 2010:

quote.para: By state and territory, what has been the total number of graduates that have been granted a reduction in their Higher Education Loan Program debt under the repayment reduction plan in the following fields: (a) nursing; and (b) education.

talker.name: Carr, Sen Kim
talker.role: Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research
talker.name: Senator Carr

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: The number of graduates to be granted a HECS-HELP Benefit will not be available until after the first applications are made to the Australian Taxation Office when people lodge their tax returns for the 2009‑10 income year from 1 July 2010.

From mid-August 2010, the ATO will provide the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations with the number of HECS-HELP Benefit applications processed and approved onwards as part of the ATO’s monthly accumulated HELP Financial Statements.

talk.start.para: asked the asked the Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research, upon notice, on 26 March 2010:

item.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. SI‑23 taken on notice during the 2009‑10 supplementary Budget estimates of the Economics Legislation Committee: When will the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation have the results.

With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 2588 (Senate Hansard, 24 February 2010, p. 1148): (a) to date, what disclaimers were used on climate change papers; and (b) can a copy of each one and the relevant paper, together with an explanation as to the material differences between them, be provided.

talker.name: Carr, Sen Kim
talker.role: Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research
talker.name: Senator Carr

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: As stated in the answer to SI-23, the research was preliminary and the data are not suitable for publication. The additional research that would be required to verify the modelling to make the results suitable for distribution or publication is not currently a high research priority for CSIRO and is not being undertaken at the moment, although CSIRO does not rule out carrying out such work in the future should changes in research priorities warrant.

CSIRO does not have a database equipped to facilitate a search of our publications based on the disclaimer used. If a disclaimer is used on a CSIRO research report, it is used to reflect the specific circumstances of the work undertaken and is developed in negotiation with the collaborators on the project. As a result, a manual search across multiple areas of CSIRO would be required to ascertain the reports relevant to this question. Following such a search, a manual review of each document would need to be undertaken in order to explain the material differences, as requested in part ‘b’ of this question. This process would require a significant diversion of CSIRO’s staff resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, on notice, on 8 April 2010:

quote.para: Did the Minister receive a communication from the Industrial Registrar, on or around 8 April 2009, advising that inquiries had commenced in relation to the Health Services Union; if so:

(a) was the communication in written form; if not, how was it communicated; (b) was it addressed to the Minister; if not, to whom was it sent; (c) can a copy be provided; if not, why not; (d) did the Minister or any staff member of her office respond to the communication; if so, can a copy of the response be provided; and (e) was the Prime Minister or any member of the Prime Minister’s staff notified by the Minister or any member of the Minister’s staff regarding the contents of the communication; if so: (i) by whom, and (ii) to whom.

talker.name: Arbib, Sen Mark
talker.role: Minister for Employment Participation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Government Service Delivery
talker.name: Senator Arbib

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: The Australian Industrial Registry commenced inquiries into the Health Services Union Victorian No 1 Branch and the Health Service Union National Office on 29 January 2009 and 6 April 2009 respectively. The functions of the Australian Industrial Registry transferred to Fair Work Australia on 1 July 2009.

The Industrial Registrar telephoned Mr Ben Hubbard (then Chief of Staff to the Minister for Education, Employment and Workplace Relations) on 8 April and advised that inquiries under section 330 of Schedule 1 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 had been commenced in relation to the Health Services Union National Office and Victorian No 1 Branch and that investigation(s) under section 331 may ensue. Mr Williams also indicated he would not be making any public comment on the matter.
There was no communication in a written form between the Industrial Registrar and the Minister or her Office and accordingly no copy can be provided.

Mr Hubbard responded to this communication verbally during the same telephone call with the Industrial Registrar by asking him whether he was comfortable for the Minister to respond to any parliamentary or media question about whether an inquiry was being undertaken by the Industrial Registrar in the following terms:

para.inline: The responsibilities of the Industrial Registrar include the financial accountability of unions and employer associations.
The Registrar is currently undertaking inquiries into the Health Services Union and is engaged in discussions with that union.
Given it is an inquiry currently with the Registrar, it would be inappropriate to discuss the matter further.

quote.para: Mr Williams confirmed he was comfortable with this approach.
No information concerning this communication was conveyed to the Prime Minister or the Prime Minister’s Office.
